channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Britons, Austerity Can Be Relative
item.description: As the government plans spending cuts, lawmakers are resisting efforts to reduce their budget as well.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: More Than 100 Vietnamese Brides Are Said to Have Disappeared From Hebei Villages
item.description: A Vietnamese woman who had lived in the area for more than 20 years helped introduce other Vietnamese women for local marriages, collecting thousands of dollars in matchmaking fees. By late November, more than 100 of the women had vanished.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at a steel factory in Handan, China. With a shortage of prospective brides, and limited financial resources, many men in the community have paid matchmakers to introduce them to Vietnamese women.

item.title: Iran Criticized for Executing Drug Offenders
item.description: Rights groups have called on the United Nations to halt its counternarcotics aid to the country because of its mandatory death penalty for drug crimes.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Former President’s Brother Is Cleared in a Corruption Case
item.description: Raúl Salinas de Gortari has been cleared of charges of illicit enrichment, ending his two decades of legal battles over charges ranging from money laundering to murder.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Family of Former Marine Held in Iran Issues Plea for Obama Not to Forget Him
item.description: The Marine’s request came as the United States intensified negotiations with the Iranians on their disputed nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: As the Ruble Swoons, Russians Desperately Shop
item.description: As Russia faced a currency crisis that prompted bickering among some top presidential allies, consumers afraid of losing their savings flooded stores, rushing to dump rubles.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A Moscow currency exchange Tuesday, when the ruble fell below 80 to the dollar.

item.title: Soccer Fans in Turkish Protests Stand Trial
item.description: The case has drawn criticism from human rights groups who accused the government of using the trial to warn other people against expressing dissent.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: U.N. Secretary General to Visit Ebola-Plagued Nations
item.description: The trip, which is to begin later this week, seems designed to send a message of solidarity with the three affected countries: Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Signals Support for New U.S. Sanctions to Pressure Russian Economy
item.description: The president’s spokesman said Mr. Obama would sign legislation passed by Congress aimed at blocking Russian state firms from Western financing and technology while also providing $350 million in military aid to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Aalsmeer Journal: Dutch Flower Auction, Long Industry’s Heart, Is Facing Competition
item.description: An auction system that helped make flowers as synonymous with the Dutch identity as wooden shoes and windmills is being buffeted by a variety of forces.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roses ready to be shipped around the globe.

item.title: Australia Tries to Figure Out How Gunman Eluded Counterterrorism Effort
item.description: Recently passed laws did not prevent Man Haron Monis, who was known to the police, from laying siege to a cafe in Sydney, leading to the deaths of two hostages.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: People in Sydney, Australia, lining up to visit a memorial site near the Lindt Chocolate Cafe.

item.title: Terror Threats Over ‘The Interview’ Are Quandary for Sony
item.description: As Sony came under pressure to cancel or postpone the release of the film, about the assassination of North Korea’s leader, the New York premiere was called off.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: The threat to attack movie theaters that show Sony’s “The Interview,” turned a continuing attack on Sony by hackers from a matter of theft to one of terrorism.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Steep Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
item.description: The Commerce Department approved a collection of tariffs on imports from China and Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:description: A Chinese solar panel company. A flood of inexpensive solar products put many American manufacturers out of business.

item.title: World Briefing: Austria: Laboratory Sees Slim Chance of Identifying Mexican Victims
item.description: Austrian forensics experts will need at least two months to see if they can identify the victims of an apparent massacre in Mexico, they said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Sydney Hostage Siege and a Nation's Identity
item.description: We Australians liked being cut off from craziness.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA BAIRD

item.title: World Briefing: Ireland: Gay-Marriage Vote Is Planned
item.description: Prime Minister Enda Kenny says the legalization of same-sex marriage will be put to a public referendum in May.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Ruling on Brotherhood Assets
item.description: An administrative court on Tuesday overturned a special committee’s decisions to seize the assets of Muslim Brotherhood leaders.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Ecuador Family Wins Favors After Donations to Democrats
item.description: A scion of the Isaías family, whose members are wanted for fraud in Ecuador, had her entry ban waived as Senator Robert Menendez lobbied Hillary Rodham Clinton’s office and the family poured tens of thousands into Democratic coffers.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Estefanía Isaías had been banned from entering the United States for visa fraud. The ban was later waived.

item.title: Taliban Besiege Pakistan School, Leaving 145 Dead
item.description: The gunmen stormed a school in Peshawar, killing more than 100 students, along with teachers, during an eight-hour rampage in retaliation against the military, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Economic Scene: Slowdown in China Bruises Economy in Latin America
item.description: China’s insatiable hunger for Latin America’s raw materials fueled the region’s most prosperous decade at least since the 1970s. That era is over.
item.dc:creator: By EDUARDO PORTER
item.media:description: An open-pit mine in the Andes mountain range near Santiago, Chile. A boom in Latin America’s raw materials is ending.
